18200.title: Joja's and Krazar's Garden
18200.description:
Just to the east of the Glade of Sanctuary is a part of the forest rarely
visited. Tall golden oak trees with thick trunks lend shade to this part
of the Golden Leaf Wood, keeping the harshness of the sun from blanching
the leaves of the tiny trees growing within. A path of hard packed black
dirt winds around, allowing the visitor to view all the plants without
stepping upon any. The ground is otherwise covered with golden oak leaves
which have fallen, lending a fresh carpet to the wood here, and somehow
not wandering onto the path. Animals feel welcome here and often visit,
careful not to trample the little trees. A small section of the garden
is devoted to a few rose plants. You see one rosebush filled with black
roses, fragrant with a heady and sensual scent. The black rose bush is
surrounded by a number of smaller rosebushes bearing tiny pink rosebuds.
Surrounding those plants are a circle of brilliant yellow tulips. A small
sign is planted in the little rose garden.

extras.description:
The tiny trees are miniature oaks, as though they were models of the larger,
more ancient golden oaks of this area. Exquisite, petite, they are a joy to
behold, and the temptation to touch the tiny golden leaves is great.

The tall thick golden oaks stand as guardians over this part of the wood.
Their thick canopy of golden leaves keeps most of the sun out, but you can
still look up and see the sky beyond when the wind rustles the high branches.

The small sign says,
Roses and Tulips
Donated by
Reldor

18201.title: Along the garden path
18201.description:
A path formed of natural rock leads southward through a lush garden.
Unlike most gardens, this one has a more wild, natural look to it.
To either side of the rock path, trees grow, their trunks thick and
coarse, their canopies offering a pleasant shade to those who travel
here. Numerous shrubs also grow here, adding thick foliage to the
lower part of the garden. A sign has been set in the soil near one
of the tall trees.

extras.description:
+-------------------+
| Botanical Gardens |
|  planted by Joja  |
|                   |
|  Kindly  Refrain  |
| From  Using Magic |
| During Your Visit |
|  To This Natural  |
|      Garden.      |
+-------+---+-------+
|   |
|   |
/////\\\\/\/\/\//////

18202.title: Along the garden path
18202.description:
The stone path meanders to the north and east here, dipping with
the land. To either side of it are tall trees, their trunks covered
with coarse bark. It is shady here, delightfully so, as a canopy of
thick leaves holds back the harshest rays of the sun during the day.
Lower to the ground, lush shrubs fill the air with freshness. A thin
stream of running water follows the path toward the east. Its origin
in the west is unseen past the thick growth of trees.

18203.title: Along the garden path
18203.description:
The rock path follows a somewhat east-west direction, lending itself
naturally to the uneven ground. To either side of the natural path
are tall, thick-trunked trees, their bark coarse and rough to the
touch. High above, a canopy of leaves lends shade to the path during
the sunniest days. A low-hanging branch promises trouble to those
who travel here without ducking low beneath it. Shrubs reach out
with thorny branches among deep green leaves. A thin stream of
running water follows the path, heading eastward. Its origin seems
to be beyond the thick growth of trees to the west.

18204.title: Along the garden path
18204.description:
The stone path meanders to the north and west here, dipping with
the land. To either side of it are tall trees, their trunks covered
with coarse bark. It is delightfully shady here, as a canopy of
thick leaves holds back the harshest heat from the sun during the
day. Alongside the trees, thick shrubs grow, their green leaves
dotted with little berries. A thin stream of running water follows
the path toward the east and the north. Its origin appears to be
beyond a thick growth of trees to the west.

18205.title: Along the garden path
18205.description:
Northward and southward the path of natural stone stretches. To either
side of it, high, thick trees surrounded by lush green shrubs send
shade from their thick canopy of leaves above. To the east is a
running stream of water heading toward the north. Several low-hanging
branches promise trouble to those who do not duck low to pass beneath
them. A lone leaf flutters downward and lands upon the rushing waters,
floating swiftly northward like a flatbottom boat.

18206.title: Along the garden path
18206.description:
The natural stone path meanders northward and southward, and branches
off eastward. Veering eastward or southward, a stream of water flows
with a pleasant gurgle. High, thick, coarse-barked trees spread a bit
of shade beneath their thick canopies of leaves. Closer to the ground,
thick shrubs fill the air with that fresh, green fragrance.

18207.title: Along the garden path
18207.description:
The rock path extends north and south through a thick woodland
of tall trees and lush shrubs. A thick canopy of leaves shades
the natural garden. The uneven ground makes travelling here a
little dangerous, with risks of turned ankles or slipping on
slick surfaces.

18208.title: Along the garden path
18208.description:
A natural rock path extends north and south over uneven ground
here. On either side of it, tall trees with thick, coarse trunks
tower above, shading all with a canopy of thick leaves. Closer
to the ground, a number of thick, thorny shrubs surround the
trees and reach out toward those who travel the path.

18209.title: End of the garden path
18209.description:
The natural rock path leads to the east. To north, west, and
south are huge trees, giant redwoods, thick as nine giants
in a huddle together. So close do they grow to one another
that there is no room for shrubs. Smaller plants seem to be
attempting to grow here in the moist soil, though. A small
stone bench is here, angled to enjoy the shade of the mighty
redwoods.

extras.description:
It appears to be made of sturdy stone, and while small, it is
strong enough to hold quite a lot of weight without cracking.

18210.title: Along the garden path
18210.description:
The natural rock path forms a T here, the crosspiece of it
stretched east and west, and the stem extending far to the
south. To the north are huge redwood trees, their trunks as
wide around as about nine giants in a huddle together. A
couple small plants have started growing among the redwoods.
The canopy of leaves high above offers shade.

18211.title: End of the garden path
18211.description:
The natural rock path leads to the west. To north, east, and
south are huge trees, giant redwoods, as thick as nine giants
in a huddle together. So close do these titanic trees grow to
one another that there is no room for shrubs. There are a few
small plants, however, which have begun to grow in the moist
soil here, despite crowded conditions. A small stone bench is
here, set at an angle to best enjoy the shade of the mighty
redwoods.

extras.description:
It appears to be made of sturdy stone, and while small, it is
strong enough to hold quite a lot of weight without cracking.

18212.title: Along the garden path
18212.description:
The natural rock path leads to east and west through the
forested garden. Alongside of it, to the south, a gurgling
stream rushes toward the east, heading downward as does
the path itself. Sunlight creeps through the canopy of
leaves above. Thick, thorny bushes reach out to travellers
on the path, luring with pretty flowers and delightful
scents.

18213.title: Along the garden path
18213.description:
The natural rock path converges here with one heading toward the
west, one toward the south, and one toward the north and east.
Looking to the east from here, you see a huge pool of water. Into
this pool the gurgling stream empties, forming a small waterfall
from this height to down there where the water is. The way down
is not safe and is not recommended to any travellers. To the south
is a stone bridge, under which the stream flows freely. During the
day, the sun breaks through the canopy of leaves here, warming the
uneven ground. The path northward slopes downward, the path south-
ward slopes upward, and the path westward remains somewhat level.

18214.title: The bridge over the gurgling stream
18214.description:
Stretching northward and southward, the natural rock path
encircles a deep pool of water. It forms a rock bridge here,
stradling the gurgling stream from the west which empties,
by way of a small waterfall, into the water below to the
east. Above, a hole in the canopy of leaves allows the sun
to shine brightly during the day, both upon the path and
bridge, and the water below and to the east.

18215.title: Along the garden path
18215.description:
The natural rock path veers toward the north and east here,
encircling a lovely huge pool to the northeast. To the north,
a rock bridge spans over a stream which forms a small waterfall
as it plunges its waters into the pool below. There is no safe
way down to the pool from here. A break in the canopy of leaves
allows the sun to shine brightly during the day, tickling the
pool's surface with its warm rays and heating the stones of
the natural path. To the west and south, tall trees rise up,
their bark rough, their trunks thick. Shrubs reach out with
thorny branches, temptingly brilliant flowers peeking out from
within thorn-infested cages.

18216.title: Along the garden path
18216.description:
To the north of the natural rock path which extends east and
west, is a deep pool fed by the waters from a gurgling stream
flowing beneath a rock bridge to the west-north-west. South of
the natural path, tall trees rise up, their leaves forming a
canopy which cannot extend above the pool. Sunlight therefore
shines upon the water's surface during the day and warms the
surface of the rocks which form the path. Short shrubs grow
between the thick tree trunks, lending foliage to the lower
levels of the forested garden. The rock path is uneven, and
the ground slopes, so that the farther east you travel, the
lower in altitude you become, the farther west, the higher.

18217.title: Along the garden path
18217.description:
The path formed of natural rock veers northward and westward
here, surrounding a deep pool of water to the northwest. From
here you can look across, west-north-westward, to a rock bridge,
and a waterfall formed from a gurgling stream, the waters of
which descend into the pool below. Tall trees growing south and
east of the path lend a canopy of leaves to form a shade, but
they do not extend over the pool, and during the day, the sun
sends its warm rays upon the water's surface, and sometimes
slips through and warms the rocks of the natural path. On a
lower level, thick shrubs grow between the tree trunks, their
foliage thick and green. The altitude changes as you travel,
rising toward the west, lowering toward the north.

18218.title: Along the garden path
18218.description:
A natural rock path encircles a deep pool of water to the west
and northwest. From where you stand, you can look west across
the way and see a rock bridge stradling a stream whose water
falls upon a rough rock face into the pool below. The path
below you is uneven, sloping downward toward the north, upward
toward the south.

18219.title: On the garden path
18219.description:
The natural rock path encircling the deep pool to the west
slopes downward to the north and upward to the south. On the
eastward side, tall trees rise up, their canopy of leaves
lending shade upon the path but none upon the water below.
Across the way, to the west, you can see a stone bridge over
a modest waterfall. Green, leafy shrubs grow between the
tree trunks, their branches reaching out toward you.

18220.title: Along the garden path
18220.description:
The natural rock paths converge at this point, encircling
the deep pool of water to the southwest and also heading
out to the east. Tall trees growing north of the path lend
shade from their canopy of leaves, but this shade only
extends to the path. The waters of the pool receive full
sunlight on a sunny day. The path slopes upward toward
the south, and also upward toward the west, but levels off
toward the east. Looking toward the southwest, across the
pool, you see a stone bridge across a stream which descends
past a rocky outcropping into the waters below.

18221.title: Along the garden path
18221.description:
On uneven ground, the natural rock path encircles the pool
to the south, sloping upward as it leads westward, downward
as it leads eastward. North of the path, tall trees grow,
their high branches extending a canopy of leaves out to shade
the path. The waters of the pool, however, remain exposed to
the direct sunlight during the day.

18222.title: Along the garden path
18222.description:
The natural path veers southward, and slopes upward, and
eastward, sloping downward, as it encircles the deep pool
to the southeast. North and west of the path, tall trees
grow, their thick, coarsely barked trunks close together,
so that only thin, but tall, shrubs grow between them.
From above, the canopy of leaves lends shade to the path,
but it does not extend to the pool, which receives the
full brunt of the sun during the day. From here, looking
south, you can see the path rising upward, and a stone
bridge arching over something.

18223.title: Along the garden path
18223.description:
The natural rock path stretches before you to the east and
west. Toward the west, it seems to meet at a convergence of
paths, rising upward. To the north and south of the path,
thin trunked trees rise, their bark smooth and grey except
where it peels, naturally, from the trunk. These trees have
not a thick foliage canopy, but thin, intermittant shade,
allowing the sunlight, during the day, to filter through.
Thick, large-leaved shrubs grow between the tree trunks, and
huge-leafed ivy covers the ground. Along the south side of
the path, a stream flows toward the east. Its origin seems
to be with the pool to the west.

18224.title: Along the garden path
18224.description:
The natural rock paths converge here, stretching to east and
west, as well as southward. Thin trunked trees rise, their
bark smooth and grey except where it peels, naturally, from
the trunk. These trees have not a thick canopy of foliage, but
thin, intermittant shade, allowing the sunlight to filter in
through the leaves during the day. Thick, large-leaved shrubs
grow between the tree trunks, and huge-leafed ivy covers the
ground. A large slab of stone spans a stream of water that
gurgles its way to the east.

18225.title: Along the garden path
18225.description:
The natural rock path extends toward the south from here,
as well as to a convergence of paths to the north. Thin
trunked trees grow here, their bark smooth and grey except
where it peels naturally from the trunk. These trees do not
have a thick canopy of foliage, but their leaves give thin,
intermittant shade, allowing the sunlight to filter in
through the leaves during the day. The ground is covered
with ivy whose leaves measure about five inches across.
Along the east side of the path, a stream flows eastward,
gurgling merrily, fed from the south and, it appears, the
west, perhaps from an opening in the rock beneath you. Along
the west side of the path, toward the south, is a flowerbed.

18226.title: Along the garden path
18226.description:
The natural rock path extends toward the north and south.
Thin trunked trees grow here, their bark smooth and grey
except where it peels from the trunk naturally. These
trees do not have a thick canopy of foliage, but their
leaves give thin, intermittant shade, allowing the sun to
filter in through the leaves during the day. The ground
is covered with a variety of ivy whose leaves measure
about five inches across. Along the east side of the
path, a stream of water gurgles northward. Along the west
side of the path is a flowerbed, neatly kept but for the
end vines of ivy which attempt to crawl over its boundaries.

18227.title: Along the garden path
18227.description:
The natural rock path stretches northward and southward.
Along the east and west sides of the path, thin trunked
trees rise up, their bark smooth and grey except where
nature has peeled it away from the trunk. These trees
were graced with a thin canopy which allows the sun to
filter through the intermittant shade it provides. Ivy,
whose leaves measure about five inches across, covers
the ground. Along the east side of the path, a stream
of water gurgles northward. Along the west side of the
path, flowers grow within a neatly kept flowerbed, into
which the ivy attempts to crawl.

18228.title: Along the garden path
18228.description:
The natural rock path stretches toward the north and
south. Along the east and west sides of the bank, thin
trunked trees rise up, their bark smooth and grey except
where nature has chosen to peel it away in paper thin
peelings. These trees were graced with a thin canopy
which allows the sun to filter through. Intermittant
shade dances upon the large (about five inches across)
leafed ivy which covers the ground. Along the west side
of the path, a flowerbed stretches north and south, the
ivy making attempts to crawl over the boundaries. Along
the east side, a stream of water gurgles northward.

18229.title: Along the garden path
18229.description:
The natural rock path veers northward and westward. Toward
the north, it is even, on level ground. Toward the west,
however, the rock path is uneven, covering ground which
slopes downward. To the northwest, a well-kept flowerbed
sits beside the path, and beyond it, a field of dark green
ivy with leaves measuring about five inches across. Amidst
the ivy, thin trunked trees rise up, lending an intermittant
shade from their canopy of leaves. The bark of those trees
is of light grey and very smooth, except where nature has
chosen to peel it away in paper-thin layers. To the east, a
stream of water gurgles northward. Its origin seems to be
within a field of ivy, perhaps a natural spring coming up
from the ground amid the vines.

18230.title: Along the garden path
18230.description:
The natural rock path extends east and west upon uneven ground
that slopes downward toward the west, upward toward the east.
To the south, a field of dark green ivy covers the ground, its
leaves measuring about five inches across. Within the field of
ivy, thin trunked trees rise up, their smooth grey bark peeling
in places. Intermittant shade covers this area, as the trees do
not have thick, large leaves. On the northern side of the path,
a neatly kept flowerbed fends off the adventurous vines of ivy
which seek to climb over its boundaries.

18231.title: Along the garden path
18231.description:
The natural rock path turns toward the north and east here,
uneven on uneven ground sloping downward toward the west and
north, sloping upward toward the east. Looking toward the
north, you see a rock face cliff, from the craggy side of
which a few die-hard trees, very small in size, have attempted
to grow. The field of dark green ivy has given way to lush
green grass, soft to walk upon. The trees here are a mixture
of those thin trunked trees with smooth, grey peeling bark, or
thicker trees of maple and elm, their dark brown bark very
rough to the touch.

18232.title: End of the garden path
18232.description:
The natural rock path stretches southward from the base of a
rough rock cliff. The land to the south gently inclines, though
the result is to make the path uneven and challenging to walk
upon. The cliff face is craggy, with small, hardy trees attempting
to grow from it. Directly before you, to the north, it seems a
little smoother, as though someone had sought to work the stone
and polish it. To the west and east of the path, lush green grass
grows, soft to the touch of bare feet walking upon it. A few elm
trees, and a couple maples, grow here.

north.description:
You sense that the smoothness of the cliff face here is indicative
of a door within the rock face. Looking closely at it, you sense
certain cracks in the rock that seem more from a construction than
natural cracking.

18233.title: Along the garden path
18233.description:
The natural rock path stretches before you to the east
and west. To the north and south of the path, you see
thin trunked trees with smooth grey, peeling bark
lending an intermittant shade to all around you. Thick,
large-leaved shrubs grow between the tree trunks, and
dark green ivy with large leaves covers the ground.
Along the south side of the path, a stream flows toward
the east. It gurgles from under a slab of rock to the
west toward another such slab of rock to the east.

18234.title: Along the garden path
18234.description:
The natural rock paths converge here, stretching to east and
west, as well as southward. During the day the sun is bright
here, for all the trees are in miniature, and no canopy of
thick leaves offers any shade. To the north of the path,
there are many rocks, and the small trees growing here cling
to those rocks with weather-toughened roots. Their trunks
have twisted and turned with the wind, some cascading, others
just leaning. Most of the trees here are from the pine and fir
families. Their bark is as tough as their will to live.

18235.title: Along the garden path
18235.description:
The natural rock path extends eastward and westward. From
here you can tell that it encircles a miniature garden, or
perhaps a garden, and forest, in miniature. The sun beats
down upon this part of the garden during the day, for there
are no tall trees to lend shading. To the north of the path,
rocks rise up that have become home to various small, hardy
trees whose weather-toughened trunks have twisted over time
with the winds. Rough roots dig into the boulders, cracking
them. Most of the trees are of the fir and pine variety, with
small, hard green needles and a certain prehistoric look. To
the south, the ground is covered with moss and grasses, and
the small trees growing there are of the deciduous kind, their
branches following the will of the natural seasons, with leaves
budding, growing, turning darker green, then to brilliant golds
and scarlets, and then, brown, falling to the ground and leaving
bare branches to rustle in the winter winds. In miniature, these
trees are exquisite, no matter the season.

18236.title: Along the garden path
18236.description:
The natural rock path turns toward the west and south here,
encircling a miniature forest garden. To the north and east,
cracked boulders serve as a perch for a number of small but
weather-hardy pine and fir trees whose trunks have been blown
in different directions over time, resulting in some rather
twisted shapes. They remain alive, however, and cling to life,
ever green. To the southwest, the ground is covered with moss
and grasses, and the small trees growing there are deciduous,
their branches following the will of the seasons, with leaves
budding, growing, turning darker green, then to brilliant golds
and scarlets, and then, brittle brown, falling to the ground
and leaving bare branches to rustle in the winter winds. In
miniature, these trees are exquisite, regardless of the season.

18237.title: Along the garden path
18237.description:
The natural rock path extends to the north and south as it
encircles a miniature forest garden. To the east, cracked
boulders serve as a perch for a number of small weather-
hardy pine and fir trees whose trunks have been blown in
different directions over time, resulting in twisted trunks
and cascading branches. They remain alive and cling to life.
To the west, the ground is covered with moss and grasses,
and the small trees growing there are deciduous, subject to
the will of the seasons, with leaves budding, growing, turning
darker green and then brilliant gold and scarlet, and finally,
brittle brown, falling from bare winter branches rustling in
the boreal winds. In miniature, these trees are exquisite at
any time of the year.

18238.title: Along the garden path
18238.description:
The natural rock path converges from three directions,
extending to the north, south, and west as it encircles
a miniature forest garden. To the east, cracked boulders
serve as a perch for a number of small weather-hardy fir
and pine trees, whose trunks, over the years, have been
twisted and bent by the wind, resulting in cascades and
leaning trees. Clinging to life, and those cracked boulders
with their weatherbeaten roots, they remain ever green.
In contrast, trees of a more deciduous nature dwell within
a miniature forest garden. Moss and grasses cover the
ground around these trees, whose leaves annually undertake
a journey of life all their own, as a metaphor for mortality:
budding, growing, turning darker green, then brilliant gold
and scarlet, finally brittle brown, falling from the branches,
leaving them bare in the boreal winds.

18239.title: The end of the garden path
18239.description:
The natural rock path extends to the north from here,
leading toward a path encircling a miniature forest
garden of deciduous trees amid grasses and moss. To
the east and south are well-kept flowerbeds. A bench
is here for resting and enjoying the view of the
miniature garden to the northnorth-west. To the west,
a few fern trees grow, surrounded by small bushes
with tiny, brilliant red roses blooming within thorny
cages.

extras.description:
It appears to be made of sturdy stone, and large enough
to hold two heavy people without cracking.

18240.title: Along the garden path
18240.description:
The natural rock path extends eastward and westward as it
encircles a miniature forest garden. To the south, cracked
boulders serve as a perch for a number of small weather-
hardy pine trees whose trunks have been blown in different
directions over time, resulting in cascading branches and
twisted trunks. Ever green, they cling to life on those
boulders. To the north, the ground is covered with moss and
grasses, and the small trees growing there are subject to
the will of the seasons, with leaves budding, growing,
turning darker green and then brilliant gold and scarlet,
and finally, brittle brown, falling from bare branches
rustling in the chill winter winds. These miniature trees
are exquisite at any time of the year. To the south, a
few fern trees grow, surrounded by small bushes with tiny,
brilliant red roses blooming within thorny cages.

18241.title: The end of the garden path
18241.description:
The natural rock path extends to the north from here,
leading toward a path encircling a miniature forest
garden of deciduous trees amid grasses and moss. To
the south is a well-kept flowerbed. To the east and
the west of the path, a few fern trees grow amidst
small bushes with tiny, brilliant red roses blooming
within thorny cages. A bench is here for resting and
enjoying the view of the miniature garden to the north-
north-east.

extras.description:
It appears to be made of sturdy stone, and large enough
to hold two heavy people without cracking.

18242.title: Along the garden path
18242.description:
The natural rock path converges from three directions,
extending to the north, south, and east as it encircles
a miniature forest garden. To the northeast, the ground
is covered with moss and grasses, and the small trees
growing there are deciduous, their branches following the
will of the seasons, with leaves budding, growing, turning
darker green, then to brilliant golds and scarlets, and
then, brittle brown, falling to the ground and leaving
bare branches to rustle in the winter winds. In miniature,
these trees are exquisite, regardless of the season. To
the west, a couple of fern trees grow, surrounded by small
bushes with tiny, brilliant red roses blooming within
thorny cages.

18243.title: Along the garden path
18243.description:
The natural rock path extends to the north and south as it
encircles a miniature forest garden. To the west, the
ground is covered with moss and grasses, and the small trees
growing there are deciduous, subject to the will of the
seasons, with leaves budding, growing, turning darker green
and then brilliant gold and scarlet, and finally, brittle
brown, falling from bare winter branches rustling in the
boreal winds. In miniature, these trees are exquisite at any
time of the year. To the west, a couple of fern trees grow
amidst small bushes with tiny, brilliant red roses blooming
within thorny cages.

18244.title: Along the natural rock path
18244.description:
A path formed of natural rock leads eastward toward what appears
to be a huge forest. To the west is the cooking area of Castle
Boovair, and to the south you see the great stone edifice rising
high, its northeast tower way above you.

east.description: You see the thick trees and a path running through them.

west.description: You see the cooking area used by the cooks of Castle Boovair.

18245.title: Along a path of polished stone
18245.description:
The stone beneath you is polished almost to a perfect shine. There
are some imperfections, though, as if someone had chipped at it in
places, though not too many places. To the east, a rocky cliff rises.
Southward, the path is rougher and begins to rise. To the west you
see lush green grass dotted with flowers of brilliant hues. The
sound of water falling rapidly into a pool delights your ears from
the north, and looking in that direction, you see that the path
continues, polished and flat as it is here.

18246.title: Along a path of polished stone
18246.description:
The stone beneath you is polished almost to a perfect shine. The few
imperfections you see serve only to highlight the smoothness of the
surface. To the east, a sheer cliff of craggy rock rises upward. West-
ward is a modest body of water, of a clear blue, reflecting the sky
and yet allowing you to see the floor of this large spring, where you
can view small plant life, multicolored rocks and stones, and maybe,
just maybe, a glimpse of something living down there. The delightful
sound of falling water comes to you from the north, and you see that
the path continues in that direction, polished and flat as it is here.
Water falls into the spring from about halfway up the rock wall to the
north, splashing into the clear blue water. Directly to the west across
the spring is another sheer cliff, and about two-thirds up, a waterfall
rushes to a ledge, where the water seems to gather and rush along to the
north and then falls rapidly down into the spring. Some overflow streams
downward along that western cliff face as the water makes its way north-
ward toward the final fall.

18247.title: Along a path of polished stone
18247.description:
The stone beneath you is polished almost to a perfect shine. There
are few imperfections in the stone here. A sheer cliff of craggy
rock rises upward to the east of you, and to the west is a modest
body of clear blue water. The loud sound of falling water comes
from the north, where you see it landing into the large spring
from a height about halfway up the rock face. As your eyes follow
the waterfall upward, you see that there is a second waterfall:
Directly to the west across the spring is another sheer cliff, and
about two-thirds up, a waterfall rushes to a ledge, where the water
seems to gather and rush along to the north and then falls rapidly
down into the spring. Some overflow streams downward along that
western cliff face as the water makes its way northward toward the
final fall.

18248.title: A bend in the path of polished stone
18248.description:
The stone beneath you is polished almost to a perfect shine. There are
few imperfections, if any at all, in the stone here. The rock wall forms
an overhang, a sort of ceiling, above you, and you are protected from a
straight downfall of water. There is such a downfall of water to your
west, but remaining on the path of polished stone will prevent you being
dashed to the rocks below which sit in the clear blue spring of water.
The path continues to the west and to the south.

18249.title: Behind the waterfall
18249.description:
The stone beneath you is polished almost to a perfect shine. Above you,
the rock wall has formed an overhanging ceiling. A waterfall forms a very
wet wall to the south, occasionally spraying water upon you where you
stand. Remaining on the path will prevent a slip and a fall to the rocks
below, where the waterfall plunges. To the north is an opening in the rock
wall, leading perhaps into a cavern. The path of polished stone extends to
the east and west.

18250.title: A bend in the path of polished stone
18250.description:
The stone beneath you is polished almost to a perfect shine. There are
few imperfections, if any at all, in the stone here. The rock wall forms
an overhanging ceiling above you, and you are protected from a straight
downfall of water. There is such a downfall of water to your east, but
remaining on the path of polished stone will prevent you being dashed to
the rocks below which sit in the clear blue spring of water. The path
continues to the east and to the south.

18251.title: Along a path of polished stone
18251.description:
The stone beneath you is polished to what appears to be a perfect shine.
Overhead is a ceiling of rock, extending from the wall to the west. To
the east is a spring of clear blue water. The path is wider here than to
the north, and from the look of it, might be wider to the south than here.
You hear the sound of water falling, both above you and to the north. If
you are careful, you can enter the spring to the east.

east.description:
You see a sparkling spring fed by a thundering waterfall. Entering
the spring from here looks safe enough, if you avoid getting too close
to the crashing water in the northern part.

18252.title: Along a path of polished stone
18252.description:
The stone beneath you is polished to a perfect shine, with few or no
imperfections. It is wide here, wide enough to enjoy a picnic or lie
down and stare up at the stars at night beyond the canopy of leaves
up above, a canopy which has opened up above the clear blue spring to
the east. The path extends northward, where it narrows a little. To
the south is an impassable wall of rock extending upward. You hear
the sound of water falling, both above you, and to the north. If
you are careful, you can enter the spring to the east. To the west
is an opening in the rock, leading to a cavern.

east.description: You see a sparkling spring fed by a waterfall.

18253.title: Wading in the Spring
18253.description:
You found your way into the spring water which forms a small shallow lake
at the base of the rocky cliffs. The water is a clear blue color, reflecting
the sky above, yet allowing one to see the lakebed below. You can tell that
there are little plants growing there, and small fish occasionally show
themselves as they dart from one plant to another. The shallow lake extends
to the north, where a waterfall fills it constantly. Looking at the lakebed
again, you do not see where the water might be draining, and yet the level
is always the same.

extras.description:
You look at the water in the spring and notice how clear it is, blue-tinted
reflecting the sky above, yet allowing you to look at the lakebed below. The
lakebed is of various sized stones, clean and polished smooth. The water of
the spring has a fresh water scent.

The fish are gold and silver, with fanning tails and long fins. They swim in
close pairs.

18254.title: Wading in the Spring near the Waterfall
18254.description:
You found your way into the spring water which forms a small shallow lake
at the base of the rocky cliffs. The water is a clear blue color, reflecting
the sky above, yet allowing one to see the lakebed below. You can tell that
there are little plants growing there, and small fish occasionally show
themselves as they dart from one plant to another. Rocks abound in the
northern section, where a waterfall crashes down, sending watery spray
everywhere. Looking at the lakebed again, you don't see where the water
might be draining, and yet the water level is always the same. The shallow
lake extends to the south.

extras.description:
You look at the water in the spring and notice how clear it is, blue-tinted
reflecting the sky above, yet allowing you to look at the lakebed below. The
lakebed is of various sized stones, clean and polished smooth. The water of
the spring has a fresh water scent.

The fish are gold and silver, with fanning tails and long fins. They swim in
close pairs.

18255.title: Behind the Waterfall
18255.description:
You stand in a cavern north of the waterfall. From that waterfall water
sprays in. The cavern itself is moderately lit by silver torches on the
eastern half, and wooden torches set in silver sconces on the western
half. The flames burn a brilliant blue, rather than the usual fiery hues
of orange and yellow. Between the torches on the eastern half are large
shields bearing the Lechium Family Crest. Between the torches on the
western half are jeweled mosaics in the shape of a deep blue rose whose
green thorny stem ends in a quill tip. There is no furniture here, but
you do see a sign above an open entrance to the east. Where one would
expect to see an open entrance to the west is, instead, a silver-barred
gate which leaves no room to sneak through, under, or over.

extras.description:
The sign is of silver, engraved with but one word:
Krazar

The gate allows a limited visibility as to what might lay beyond.
Attached to the bars is a silver plate with a single word engraved
upon it:
Joja

18256.title: The Massive Cavern of the Lord of Fear
18256.description:
As you enter this mammoth cave, you are immediately
struck not only by its huge proportions, but also by the
warm moist air that is very fresh and crisp in your lungs.
The smooth walls are a clay red color and are lined with
flickering torches of pure silver. Between each torch
are large shields bearing the Lechium Family Crest. You
notice a large inscription upon the floor.

extras.description:
Those that here enter:  Lay aside ye arms, for this
is a place of study and peace. Those that seek the
Crest are like family and should not attempt to injure
each other. Penalties for shedding blood here are quite
severe.

18257.title: The Massive Cavern of the Lord of Fear
18257.description:
The walls broaden and part here to reveal a room full of
light from a staircase leading to the top of what appears
to be a tower built through the top of the cavern. The
floor of the cavern is lined with beautiful rugs of many
different cultures. Upon the walls hang tapestries alive
with many different hues.

18258.title: The Massive Cavern of the Lord of Fear
18258.description:
Upon the far wall of the cavern a huge hearth radiates a
warm and cozy heat. The massive fire crackles amiably
and sends light bouncing everywhere. Over the hearth are
two magnificent portraits. On the left is a massive portrait
of Krazar in full battledress. Upon the right is a glowing
portrait of Joja.

extras.description:
His Lechium Family Sword is wielded in his right hand, and his
Very Heavy Sword is in his left. His face is stoic and seems
chisled in stone.

Her majestic wings are outstretched and illuminated by a blinding
light behind her. Her face is highlighted by crown of blue roses
and she has a determined yet peaceful look upon her visage.

18259.title: The Massive Cavern of the Lord of Fear
18259.description:
You are struck by the sheer size of Krazar's library. Even
more dazzling is the centerpiece of the room, a pedestal
made of pure platinum on which sits the huge compendium of
family history. As you move to the pedestal, it automatically
adjusts to your size so that you can easily access the compendium.

18260.title: The Massive Cavern of the Lord of Fear
18260.description:
Lining the walls of the cavern here are glorious suits of
armor. The many different varieties of battlegear glimmer
in the torch light. Above each suit of armor hang weapons
of every variety and size. This part of the cavern appears
to be a monument to the warrior guild.

18261.title: Behind the Silver Gate
18261.description:
As you enter this dark passage, you see smooth stone walls of a
clay red hue lined with flickering dark blue wax candles in shiny
silver sconces. Between each candle are tapestries depicting the
deep blue rose whose green, thorny stem ends in a quill tip. In
each tapestry the quill tip appears to have written words upon a
parchment. The first one on the right says, 'Love'. The first on
the left says, 'Loyalty'. The second on the right says, 'Diplomacy',
and the second on the left says, 'Natural Power.' The floor is of
the same clay red stone as the walls. The ceiling, however, is so
high you cannot see it, but you know it is there.

18262.title: The Massive Cavern of the Lady of Purity
18262.description:
The walls broaden and part here to reveal a room full of light.
A silver staircase leads upward to the top of what appears to be
a tower built through the top of the cavern. The floor of the
cavern is lined with beautiful rugs of swirly designs, with greens
and blues predominating, as though they were mimicking water. Upon
the walls hang tapestries alive with many different hues,
portraying woodlands, prairies, meadows, hillocks, mountains,
deserts, water, and tunnels beneath the ground.

18263.title: The Massive Cavern of the Lady of Purity
18263.description:
Upon the far wall of the cavern, a huge hearth radiates a warm and
cozy heat. The massive fire crackles amiably and sends light
bouncing all over. Above the hearth are two magnificent portraits.
On the left is a massive portrait of Joja wearing hunter-crafted
leathers. On the right is a portrait of Krazar wearing an open-
neck tunic and leathers. Along the north wall, in silver frames
that set them apart from the clay red walls, are six smaller
pictures, labelled with the names, Kalkyr, Burthain, Dalvimyr,
Trevyr, Agharil, and Jyracil. On the western wall beside the
fireplace are two tall pictures, labelled with the names Bludgwuar
and Agryr. A smaller picture between these two is labelled with the
name, Sengeril.

extras.description:
The large rectangular picture has a swirly silver frame
reminiscent of a unicorn's horn. Within that frame is a
background of a forest of oak trees with golden leaves,
tall ones and very small ones, though the small ones look
about as old as the tall ones. The forest floor is
covered in leaves of gold and scarlet. Leaning against
one tree is a huge shield bearing three six-pointed stars
azure on a field blank, two above, one below, centered.
Standing next to the tree is a huge man, with muscles
seemingly of iron, leathery skin tanned from spending much
time in the sun. His long, black hair streams down his
massive shoulders and flows down his back. His legs are as
thick as the tree supporting the shield. His tunic is open,
exposing a muscular chest adorned with a tattoo of an eagle
soaring over an enraged viper. Across this tattoo is
another one, that of a well-etched battleaxe. His bare arms
bear tattoos as well. On his right forearm you see a dagger,
above the dagger and running the rest of the span of his
massive arm is a finely etched broadsword. On his left arm,
a large warhammer is deeply engraved in his calloused flesh.
An aura of light blue surrounds Krazar Lechium, and he carries
a very heavy sword engraved with his name, a sword bearing
very sharp edges and appearing to be of forged iron.

The large rectangular picture has a swirly silver frame
reminiscent of a unicorn's horn. Within that frame is a
background of a forest of oak trees with golden leaves,
tall ones and very small ones, though the small ones look
about as old as the tall ones. The forest floor is covered
in leaves of gold and scarlet. In the foreground is a small
tree with green leaves and deep blue roses growing upon it.
The trunk of the little rose tree is covered with thorns.
Standing by the tree is a beautiful grey-elven lady. She
is slim and wears leathers which appear to be crafted by a
hunter. Dark brown in color, they match her dark hair
streaked with red which flows freely down from her head
and way down her back, blown a little by the forest breeze.
Her green eyes gaze in many directions at once, very much
like one of those portraits that seem to follow you as you
walk past them. Behind her, huge wings with feathers
reminiscent of a giant eagle's rise up. While obviously
hers, the wings seem slightly out of place, as though they
should have been granted to a giant. They arch gracefully
behind her. Despite being winged, the Angel Joja firmly
stands upon the ground. Next to her on one side, a white
baby unicorn rubs its neck against her legs. On the other
side, a trollish looking thing crouches on all fours,
reaching her shoulder in its lowered height. One of her
hands gently touches the baby unicorn behind the ears,
the other hand gently rests upon the trollish beast's
shoulder. A smile on her face speaks of the joy she feels
among the beasts and the woods.

An extremely large troll stands by a massive iron gate by
a stone wall into which battle runes and mottos have been
inscribed. His clothes are a dark greyish-green that would
fade easily into leaf or shadow. Kalkyr Krull is tall and
hard, broad-shouldered, with blue eyes like frozen mountain
lakes. His skin is a dark green color, almost brown, making
his clothes seem almost a second skin, and his almond eyes
stand out like sapphires. His face is one that does not
resemble most trolls, as it is unmarred by scars and far too
beautiful in a way. Elven-like ears add to the peculiarity of
his face and diminish his trollish features perhaps beyond
certainty. There is a touch of inky black in his fiery red
hair held back by a woven leather cord. Although his features
seem to be mixed from many descents, his stance can only be
described as determined. Beyond his greyish-green cloak you
see a glimmering tattoo of a dagger on his left forearm. On
his right forearm is a similarly glimmering tattoo, this one
of a broadsword. Around his neck hangs a blood red necklace
with the insignia of the Bloodknights of Steel etched upon it.
One hand rests on the long hilt of his huge battleaxe, the
shaft of which extends beyond the sharp curved blades and
rests upon the hard stone ground.

A female troll stands by a tapestry of an intricately woven
pentagram, her stance reminiscent of a flirty barmaid. Her
clothing accentuates her noticeable bust, and you can see
the smooth purple skin of her legs. Her face is also purple,
with a bronzed shine to it, and flawless. Her deep crimson
eyes match her lips, under which two small white fangs
protrude. Long elven ears peek out from her dull blonde hair,
tied in a myriad of braids. She has multiple piercings in
her nose. The expression on her face is difficult to place,
although most who have viewed this picture have concluded
that Burthain Krull did not want to pose for any artist at
the time.

A young giant of a man with almond-shaped green eyes,
Dalvimyr Krull regards you from a portrait. He is standing
by a fir tree, two hunting hounds at his ankles. His long
dark hair is tied back with a leather strap, pulling it
close enough to his head that his pointed elvish ears stick
up and out through it. His skin is flawless and unblemished,
and he wears clothing as seen on noblemen and royals, satins
and velvets, fur linings and trim. Around his neck a golden
chain bears an amulet of a leaf, wrought in gold also, and
studded with emeralds. Dalvimyr's fingers are adorned with
many bejeweled rings, a veritable rainbow in faceted gems
reflecting light.

A stocky, greenish-grey man clad in very little armor stands
with an unexpected grace. Trevyr Krull's coarse, mottled
greenish-brown hair cascades past his short, sharply pointed
ears down to the middle of his back. His pink, almond-shaped
eyes are sunken into his head, gazing out over an almost
troll-like muzzle. A thin, hawk-like nose projects itself from
the muzzle. Very muscular, his body is larger and perhaps
clumsier than that of most who wear a belt of rank within the
martial arts. Yet he must move with extreme grace and fluidity,
for the belt around his waist is black, adorned with silvery
praying mantises. His hands are grotesquely marred with burns.
Visible on his left pectoral is an intricate tatoo of a
silvery dagger. Around the silvery dagger is a tatoo of a
blood red broadsword, ripping down his abdomen and disappearing
just beneath his belt. Down his right arm, a huge tatoo of a
brown-handled warhammer with a silver head designates his
last ranking within the Steel Clan before he was named as
Envoy.

A large man in monk garb stands with ease amid a forest of
autumnal trees, their crimson, gold, and orange leaves a bright
contrast to the man with the serious demeanor. Agharil Krull
appears to be of trollish descent, however, he is obviously not
a pureblooded troll. His hulking, chiseled body and olive-
colored skin bely the maredly elven features which are apparent
in his countenance. With almond-shaped eyes and a rather
handsome face by trollish standards, Agharil is very unique-
looking. He wears only the simple garb of a monk: a light robe,
some rings and bracers, and a pair of simple necklaces. His
long, sable hair is silkier and straighter than the average
troll would have. This mane of hair frames a face free of warts
and hair, but marked by several small scars. In his eyes one
can detect intelligence and awareness, and despite his muscular
frame, he probably moves quite deftly, for it takes some grace
to earn a brown belt. Mantises outlined in gold thread cavort
on his belt. A runic symbol has been burned into the flesh of
his right arm, and on his left arm is the mark of a dagger.

The boyish face and slim body which regard you from this
portrait belong to Jyracil Krull. He stands by a garden
of brilliantly hued flowers. Jyracil wears a plain tunic of
forest green, and leather breeches. His light hair is
shoulder-length and thick, but the points of his elvish ears
peek out at the sides of his head. Around his neck are two
golden chains. On his ring fingers he wears two plain silver
rings. In one hand he holds a sword somewhat incorrectly. It
is a gleaming silver blade with many runes inscribed upon it,
and probably a ceremonial blade rather than a serious sharp one.

Standing amidst a summer-green forest thick with trees is a
green-skinned troll, Bludgwuar Stregheria. Behind him, to
left and right, are two hounds, dark brown and black their
coats, with black noses, and sharp eyes. The troll wields a
knife in one hand, a staff in the other. His body is covered
with furs and tanned skins, stretching over swelled muscles.
Dark yellow eyes keenly gaze at you from the picture, the look
of a killer. Sticking out between Bludgwuar's lips are pointy
teeth. Wavy black hair thickly covers his head, a lock of it
falling away from the rest and curving to the right between
his eyebrows. Carved as though with a blade dipped in acid
into his left arm are the words, 'veneratio, proelium, rectus-
ordinarius'. On Bludgwuar's right arm, in the same fashion, is
the word, 'daiitokumyouou'. Many colorful tatoos stand out
against his dark green skin, many of swords and other weapons
crossed. A battleaxe stands out above the others. Around his
neck, a dull grey chain holds a fearsome amulet, a bloodied
gauntlet mounted upon a sword, the symbol of a BloodKnight of
Steel, the most feared of Crusaders.

Agryr Stregheria stands in a field of green grass and multi-
colored wildflowers. By his side two lean hounds stand with
ears and eyes alert. His green-tinted skin contrasts with
his red-streaked black hair which grows thickly on his head.
Pointed ears stick out. His eyes, bright green like twin
emeralds, sit perfectly in a face of smooth, flawless skin.
Agryr appears to be more trollish than elvish, yet elements
of both races are present in his physique. He has the slender
look of an elf, yet is broader and more muscular. A fiery red
and orange comet tatoo flies above an intricate battleaxe
whose handle is wrapped by leafy vines. The colors of the
tatoos are vibrant and compelling, peeking out from a V-neck
opening of his fur and tanned leather armor. Upon his left
forearm is a blood-red dagger. At the center of his forehead
is a small but beautifully worked broadsword pointing down
such that its hilt acts as crossarms in a 'cross'. As you
look more closely at this small broadsword, you notice tiny
words worked into the blade, 'Honor' and 'Courage in the
Hunt'. Above his forearm just above the blood-red dagger is
a detailed warhammer done in pure white, contrasting with
Agryr's green skin.

A large warrior with heavily trollish features stands by an
iron gate and a smooth rock wall. Sengeril Stregheria is
dressed in beautifully detailed armor. His skin is a flawless
ebony-green, but his pointed ears and narrow bone structure
in his face give him a very elfin look. Unlike most trolls
who are incredibly large built masses of meat and muscle,
Sengeril is incredibly lean. His muscle and sinew look almost
unnatural, as if sculpted from solid rock. Long, snow-white
hair flows down onto Sengeril's shoulders with the exception
of a small, red line. A dull glow radiates from pupilless
blood-red eyes which stare at you from the picture and yet
seem unfocused. His armor is finely crafted mithril engraved
with many symbols of the royal family of Dhaes Drae Aesilon.
A blood red cape of fine silk hangs down from his neck, caught
by a breeze. A large sword is strapped over his shoulder,
its blade seemingly tinted with blood. Carved into the blade
are the words, 'ELF SLAYER'.

18264.title: The Massive Cavern of the Lady of Purity
18264.description:
You are struck by the sheer size of Joja's library. A number
of books grace the bookshelves here which were carved from
the stone itself. Throughout the library a number of chairs
are scattered. Next to each chair is a standing sconce bearing
a single dark blue candle kept constantly lit. The hard rock
floor is covered by a huge carpet of many colors, with dark
blue dominating and contrasting with gold, crimson, green,
purple, and orange.

18265.title: The Massive Cavern of the Lady of Purity
18265.description:
Lining the walls of the cavern here are a number of staffs,
knives, and pelts. A shelf carved in the stone wall holds
a number of jars containing herbs. A collection of seeds
sits within a box set on one shelf. Polished horns and
antlers adorn part of the wall, as well as a few trophy
heads from various animals. A large club leans against
the corner of two of the walls. This part of the cavern
appears to be a monument to the ranger guild.

18266.title: The Trebuchet Above the Lechium Cavern
18266.description:
Looking about the tower, you realize that you are
standing within a huge trebuchet. The entire tower is
surrounded by huge redwood trees which block your view
of the surrounding forest. Standing where you are, it
seems as if you only need utter the word "Release", and
you would be flung halfway across Thera!

18267.title: The Greenhouse Above the Lechium Cavern
18267.description:
Looking about the tower, you realize that you are standing
within a glass structure. The smooth stone floor rises up
at the walls to about six inches. Then the stone walls end
and the walls of glass begin. These walls are very thick
and by no means weak and shatter prone. Along the glass
walls are wooden tables fit perfectly with the curve. Upon
those tables are a number of small pots containing plants
in various stages of growth. The air here is humid and warm.
Beyond the thick panes you see a forest, and a garden with
a pathway running through it that seems to spell something.
Glittering in the light, a shiny silver stair leads downward.

18268.title: The Massive Cavern of the Lady of Purity
18268.description:
The walls of the cavern here are adorned with silver sconces
and dark blue candles kept burning. Between the sconces are
parchments framed with polished wood. You see a number of
such parchments, each one numbered and worded in Common. The
floor is covered with a number of throw rugs made from the
pelts of large beasts. The pelts are soft to the touch and
clean, somehow, despite the fact that people walk through
here with their outdoor boots on.

extras.description:
The framed parchment marked with a '1' contains the words,
Our achievements are shaped by the terrain of our lives and
the strength of the foundations we set. In building the
life we have imagined, we must be true to our beliefs
dare to be ethical, and strive to be honorable.
For Integrity is the highest ground
to which we can aspire.

The framed parchment marked with a '2' contains the words,
Thou canst choose thine actions,
but thou canst not choose the outcomes.
Natural law doth govern outcomes.

The framed parchment marked with a '3' contains the words,
What people do to us hurteth us not.
'Tis our chosen response to what
they do which inflicteth pain.

The framed parchment marked with a '4' contains the words,
Nothing canst make thee to feel inferior
without thine own consent.
Nobody canst take from thee thy self-respect
if thou givest it not to them.

The framed parchment marked with a '5' contains the words,
What is important to another person
must be as important to thyself
as that other person is to thee.

The framed parchment marked with a '6' contains the words,
Strength lieth in differences,
not in similarities.

The framed parchment marked with a '7' contains the words,
More noble 'tis to give thyself completely
to one individual,
than to seek to give thyself in part
to the masses.

The framed parchment marked with an '8' contains the words,
Love dieth not a natural death.
It dieth because we know not how to replenish its source.
It dieth of blindness, errors, and betrayals.
It dieth of illness and wounds, weariness,
witherings,tarnishings, and neglect.

The framed parchment marked with a '9' contains the words,
All love that hath not a base in friendship
is like a castle with a base upon the sand.

The framed parchment marked with a '10' contains the words,
When the power of love overcometh the love of power
the soul willt know peace.

The framed parchmet marked with an '11' contains the words,
Let thy quest not be to seek for love,
but to seek and find
all barriers within thyself
that thou hast built against it.

The framed parchment marked with a '12' contains the words,
Everything in nature containeth
all the power of nature.

18269.title: The Massive Cavern of the Lady of Purity
18269.description:
Blazing cressets atop natural rock columns light the rocky
walls and floor. The rock floor is bare of any cloth or
fur, and you can see where water has collected in the few
low spots, undoubtedly tracked in from a wet place. More
than a few huge glass-topped tables formed of stone protrude
from the walls, the stone part of the wall, but the glass
obviously added later. Within the tables are collections
of things. Each table is labelled by number.

extras.description:
You look through the glass of the stone table marked '1'
and see an exhibit marked,
"Trophies from the Outlaw War":
a poncho from the carcass of Crulthix
( 3) a steak of Namar            a steak of Leila
( 5) a steak of Sorin            a steak of Tauvi
a steak of Krizin      ( 3) a steak of Zinfister
a steak of Splythe     ( 2) a steak of Thedus
a steak of Ranthir     ( 6) a steak of Amenotep
( 3) a steak of Gharien          a steak of Sterbefall
( 3) a steak of Aerdrie          a steak of Grimark
( 2) a steak of Ventar           a steak of A cloaked figure
( 7) a steak of Zhentrezes  ( 2) a steak of Blemdumen
( 2) a steak of Cethegis         a steak of Lyllewl
( 2) a steak of Bainus           a steak of Vindillas
a steak of Supatha          a steak of Avaisil
( 4) a steak of Murdok           a steak of Luin
( 2) a steak of Kithis           a steak of Janoplin
( 3) a steak of Vrith            a steak of Kyista
( 2) a steak of Veth             a steak of Gorlab
a steak of Norlys           a steak of Karvik
a steak of Alunan      ( 3) a steak of Connell
a steak of Arog             a steak of Pirlisia
